The boundless expansion and versatility OF
intellect that illuminate the writings OF
Madame de Stael and Miss Porter, have
filled Europe and America with admiration
and the erudite and splendid productions OF
Miss Edgeworth, have enriched English lit
crature, with as pure and sparkling an ore
as philosophy conld raise out OF an mex


haustibe mine, that is alive to the various
sympathies and feelings that govern and d.
rect the passions of humanity. In the WORKS
of Lady Morgan we find every subject ar
rayed in the seducing charms OF sentiment
al sorcery, and rendered still more attract


i've by the graceful drapery OF tiowery dic-
ton. In the romantic enthusiasm OF patriot
ism-in the passion of energy that dlstln-
guish her vindication of her country; IN the
magnificence OF style, and in the VIVID por-
traiture of Irish character, she is emineneiy


superior to Miss Edgeworth. On reading
| her .HQiy' we are astonshcd ny the pr'eht
efYulgence of her views, the power OF her &c,
scrintions. and the philosophic musings and
apt conceptions, which pervade the pages o'
| fiat celebrated work-a work which, while
il 6lled the sceptered despots OF the "Holy
Alliance with terror, drew torth from
| T ord Bvrop. the memorable and laudatory
compliment, which our fair country women
prize more highly than all the imperial com
mendations which the Cesars and Czars
could bestow upon their aduating favor
lites.. We compassionate the tasteless crit
ic who is not delighted with the beauty O
her style, and the glow of her sentiments


when she touches the affections and passions


of the human heart; as, like Goethe and KOS


Sc seau, m her pages are fronght with that spiri


of impassioned eloquence, which lmpresse'


upon her composition the seal of rapturou


cnchansment, and enlarges our ideas. ant


liberalizcs our mind, while it strengthen


those bonds of philanthrophy that bind us u


our fellow-creatures. The power OF woman


in this literary age. is become as potent iron
intellectual influence as she was tormerl.
FEMALE GENIUS AND BEAUTY.

How seldom one thinks of himself The
gay, busy world as it revolves its ceaseless
orbit-the things OF fashion and opinion as
they dance before the vision--the wild whlil
of to day, which is wrcckless oi tomorrow,
all consume the sands of life, and yet we new
cr pause to reflect upon ourselves
Ii has been said, that all are selfish by na-
ture: and vet no remark was ever more un-
lust. We will adduce tor example your
brightest specimen OF genius-one VINO mas
the Promethean spark in his soul, who LOOKS
upon the landscape and loves it--who sees
virtue and tails PROSTATE at its shrine-ahu
vet ractices yce-Nice is relative term
the Hndoo priest. who urges the widow 70
mount the funeral pile of murder is less
guilty of crime on account of his ignorance,
than the Christian who breaks less morai
tie. Sogenius, (which knows the right and
yet the wrong pursucs" is vicious when COM
pared with folly.


! How few of the favored sons OF talent act
up to their high profession. In all arts III
all sciences, genius, like comet, Is ever &C.
centric, and its irregularty, comparatively
speaking, is a crime--can 1t be reduced TO
consistencyl can education and mind be LED
to adop, the plain morality of an honest yeo-
man!


Method is every thing-a virtuous sys-
TEN will prove an overmatch for evil habits;
and Saturday Evening should recall one
from the troubles and outward assaults OF
the world to an inward communication with
himself. his conduct, his location as to here
and hereafter. 1t should be like the cottage
of the lover and the iaborcr-he should sit
down beside the freside of his own heart,
call around him his children. which are his
thoughts and with them enter into judS-
ment as to the past, and from this calculate
upon better things to be performed In the
future. Men read history to be informed OF
the past--thcy gravely calculate from pre-,
diction what may ensue from the aspect ol
the present political world--and yet forgc'
to look at the past Of their own lives, and tc
draw a horoscope of their future existence
even upon earth. The world is selfish, 1t Is
sad--and yet how little of mans life IS de-
voted to himself True it is that ambition
claims part-the love of Distinction O
pleasure, of ease, are creditors which cair
more-but real selfshness, which is asld'
from these outward objects, and which re


ates to the settlement of our accounts Will
ourselves, takes no part in the drama OF eX


stence; and is untried before the forum o


conscience.


How seldom do we strive to be acquainted


with ourselves! with the springs OF actor


which govern us-the course OF life whlcl


we pursue-the very detail of criminal care


lessness which marks our conduct--all unno


tced as we sweep onward to death.


Is there no remedy?--let each Saturda.


night sit in Judgment upon the other SIX day


of the week, and let the Sabbath be devot


ed to virtuous resolutions, penitcnce all


prayer.

from personal attraction. Still we must

Father of all! whose love has given
The boon that lifts my thoughts to heaven!
Teach me to guard with watclful care
The treasure thou hast sent me here
AND while my purest feelings flow,
With warm affections fullest glowi
oh let thy strength pcrvade my heart,
Aud teach me all a mothers part
ms CHERISHED babe which fills my arms,
And cheers me with its opening charms,
As thine in life, is thine in death;-
us earliest and its latest breath
Zane, and must go at thy decree
us life is only lent to me!


Then teach me with thy heavenly skill
io wait obedicntly thy viii!


and while train its thoughts to rise
from earth towards its native skies,
may my trembling heart prepare
nnoyleld it to thy heavenly care,
W Mhen thy sad messenger shall come
bear ito its safest home.


~. nut II thy mercy spares it now,


e's go schldhood's bloom, to manhood's S glow.

rof none but those who OWN thy SWAY
Sah safely tread the narrow way

go, breathe no more that simple air,
Though soft and sweet thy wild notes swell
To me the only tale they tell


Is cold despair
heard it on from lips as fair.
heard it in as sweet q tone
Now am left on earth alone


And She is-where'
How have those well-known sounds renewed
The dreams Of earlier, happier hours,
When ltc--a desert now-was strewea


With fairy fiowers!--
Then all was bright, and fond, and tmr'-
Now flowers are faded, joys are He'd
And heart and hope are with the dead


For she ls-where'
Can then love the air she loved
Can then hear the melting strain
Which brings her to my soul again


Calm and unmov'd'-
And thou to blame my tears forbear;
For while list, sweet mad! to thee,
Remembrance whispers, such was she,'-


And she is where"

When Col Washington first resided AZ
Mount Vernon, both the mansion house and
estate were inconsiterabe. All the em5el-
lishments of the house and grounds are ow-
iEr to his creative hand. Prior TO the war
of independence, he was much attached 10
the pleasures of the chase, and Is described
AS a bold and fearless rider. He Kept
hounds for short time after the Revolution,
but declined hunting altogether about 1857
or '88.


He was never disposed to conviviallty, but
liked the cheerful converse OF the social
board; indulging in no games OF chance' eH-
cept in the oldcn times, when required 10
make up party at whist, in playing tor
trlfle, although for many years, play OF al
kinds was unknown in his household. At
ter his retirement from public lie, all the
time he could spare from his library, was
devoted to the improvement OF his estates,
and the elegant and tasteful arrangement OF
his house and grounds He was his own
surveyor; and the disposition and appear
ance Of his farms, gave evident proofs that
the genius of useful improvement had d.
rected it's energies with beneficial as well as
ornamental effects.


Asa master Of slaves, General Washing
ton was consistent, as in every other rela-
ton of his meritorious life. They were
comfortably lodged, Ted, and clothed; re-
Qnired to do full and tair share OF duty
we'll cared for in sickness and old age, ana
kept in strict and proper discipline These,
we humbly conceive, comprise all the char-
tiles Of slavery To his old servants, whose
long and faithful services rendered them
worthy Of attachment and esteem. he vas
most kind. Ills huI tsman and Revolutions
~ attendant, WIN Lee, commonly called
Billy, was specially provided tor, and sur
yivcd his master a good many years. WIN
had been stout, active man, and famous
horseman, but, from accident, was Cripple
MANY years before his death, which occur
J red at a very advanced age. This ancient
( follower, both in the chase and war, formed
most Interesting relic of the Chief, and
received considerable largcssc from the vis'
tiers to Mount Vernon. The slaves were
\ left. TO be emancipated at the death OF Mrs
WA ohingten; but it was found necessary
! (fOr Hrudenta.k rcasons) to give them then
/ freedom in one year after the Generals de-
cease. Although many of them, with
view to their liberation, had been instructed
in mechanic trades, yet they succeeded very
badly as freemen: so true is the MAXIM
"that the hour which makes man slave
takes half his worth away"

At the commencement OF the hostilitles,
in l775, Bishop being too old for active SER
vice, was left at home in charge of the man.
ufacturing establishments of the household.
where the veteran would flourish his cane,
exactng as perfect obedience as though he
had been ON parade. A comfortable house
had been built for him; he had married; and
looking no more toward his native land, he
was contented to pass the remainder OF his
DAYS on the domain of his patron, where he
rested from labor, in the enjoyment of eve
ry possible ease and indulgence-the re-


ward of his long and faithful services. In
his comfortable homestead, and hoary with


age, he would delight the young with tales


of fearful interest of the Indian wars, while


his own wars ended, at peace with the world,


he feebly trimmed the lamp of life, which,
having burned for more than eighty years,


could but for little longer be kept from


sinking in its socket


otwithstanding his perfect reverence for


his patron, this old soldier weuld sometimes.


presuming on the privilege of age and long


services, chafe his protector on points of ex-
! pedency, though never on those of obedi-


cnce. The General would assume lofty


tone, saying it is very WE'LL sir; if you are at


length tired of my service, you are at per-


feet liberty to depart. The ancient follow


er of Braddock, however, knew his man,


and knew exactly what was best to do; he


wisely became silent; and the storm which


appeared to be brooding quickly passed e.


way, when a returning sunshine cheered
with the warmth of its kindness the veteran


of '56.


The Washington family were subjected


10 hereditary gout-the Chief never expert
enced pang. His temperance, and the en-
, ergetic employment of both his body and


mind, seemed to forbid the approach of a dis


ease. which severely afflicted several of his


kindred. His illnesses were of rare occur


renee, but were particularly severe; his a


version to the uses of medicine was extreme:


for, even when in great suffering, it was only


by the entreaties of his lady, and the respect


tul, yet beseeching look, of his oldest friend
and companion in arms, (Dr. James Craik, }


chat he could be prevailed upon to take the


slightest preparation of medicine. He cer-


tanly never had children. We recolect a


lady who called herself his daughter. She
was a fine looking woman, but without any


particular likeness to the Chief, nor can we
consider that as pardonabe vanity in


child, which duplicates the honor OF pa


rent.


The remarkable degree Of admiration and


awe that was felt by every one, upon the
, first approach to Washington, evidences the


imposing power and sublimity which belongs
to real greatness. Even the frequenters Of
the Courts OF Princes were sensible of this
, exalted feeling, when in the presence of the
hero, who, formed for the highest desti-
nics. bore an impress from nature, which
| declared him to be one among the noblest Of
her works.


Those who have only seen the Lead
, er of Armies and the Chief Magistrate of
the Republic can have but an imperfect idea
, of the same being, when merged in the re-
tired citizen, embosomed amid his family
/ and friends, cultivating the social and domes
: tic virtues, and difusing pleasure and hap
! piness to all around him.


$ Persons in general have been in error, in
e supposing that there belonged to this awful

i vioaters of those institutes which promote
y peace and good will among men; but he was
!, forbearing to the imperfectons of humac
!, kind, where they arose from the passions


only, and not the dcpravities of the heart.
: He was reserved to the many, but there
= were chosen few, who, having passed thai
!; barrier, were wooed by his friendship t
+ push their fortunes, till they finally gainee
o footing in the citadel of his esteem.


e He had a tear-tor we have seen it shct
y with parental solicitude over the manifold
d errors and folles of our unworthy youth
t. lie shed a tear Of sorrow for his suffering
IS country in the dark hour of her destiny, anl

kind Office, in order to endear her slill more

that she might moderate his ecstacies by
the persuasion of voice which had so much
power over him as hers ever had. When
She began to take off the bandage from his
ewes, she said, "tell me in what manner that
love you have always professed for me, en-
tered into your heart, its usual admittance
is through the eyes!"


He answered, dear Lydia, if by seeing l
am no more to distinguish the step OF her
love, when she approaches me, but to change
the sweet and frequent pleasure for such an
amazement as experienced the little time
lately saw; or if am to have any thing
besides which may take from the sense
have ot'what appeared most pleasing to me
at that time, ( which apparition it seems was
| you, pull out these eyes before they ieao
to be ungrateful to you. or undo myself.
wish for them but to see you; pluck them
/ from their sockets. if they are to make me
forget you."


Lydia, delighted with these assurances
withdrew the bandage and gave him light te
his incxpressiblc JOY and satisfaction. :,


In all his conversation with her he manifest
cd but very faint ideas OF any thing Whict
had not been received at the ear.

full articles.headline: FEMALE GENIUS AND BEAUTY.
full articles.article:
The boundless expansion and versatility OF
intellect that illuminate the writings OF
Madame de Stael and Miss Porter, have
filled Europe and America with admiration
and the erudite and splendid productions OF
Miss Edgeworth, have enriched English lit
crature, with as pure and sparkling an ore
as philosophy conld raise out OF an mex


haustibe mine, that is alive to the various
sympathies and feelings that govern and d.
rect the passions of humanity. In the WORKS
of Lady Morgan we find every subject ar
rayed in the seducing charms OF sentiment
al sorcery, and rendered still more attract


i've by the graceful drapery OF tiowery dic-
ton. In the romantic enthusiasm OF patriot
ism-in the passion of energy that dlstln-
guish her vindication of her country; IN the
magnificence OF style, and in the VIVID por-
traiture of Irish character, she is emineneiy


superior to Miss Edgeworth. On reading
| her .HQiy' we are astonshcd ny the pr'eht
efYulgence of her views, the power OF her &c,
scrintions. and the philosophic musings and
apt conceptions, which pervade the pages o'
| fiat celebrated work-a work which, while
il 6lled the sceptered despots OF the "Holy
Alliance with terror, drew torth from
| T ord Bvrop. the memorable and laudatory
compliment, which our fair country women
prize more highly than all the imperial com
mendations which the Cesars and Czars
could bestow upon their aduating favor
lites.. We compassionate the tasteless crit
ic who is not delighted with the beauty O
her style, and the glow of her sentiments


when she touches the affections and passions


of the human heart; as, like Goethe and KOS


Sc seau, m her pages are fronght with that spiri


of impassioned eloquence, which lmpresse'


upon her composition the seal of rapturou


cnchansment, and enlarges our ideas. ant


liberalizcs our mind, while it strengthen


those bonds of philanthrophy that bind us u


our fellow-creatures. The power OF woman


in this literary age. is become as potent iron
intellectual influence as she was tormerl.

full articles.headline:
THE MONITOR.

SATURDAY EVENING.
full articles.article:
How seldom one thinks of himself The
gay, busy world as it revolves its ceaseless
orbit-the things OF fashion and opinion as
they dance before the vision--the wild whlil
of to day, which is wrcckless oi tomorrow,
all consume the sands of life, and yet we new
cr pause to reflect upon ourselves
Ii has been said, that all are selfish by na-
ture: and vet no remark was ever more un-
lust. We will adduce tor example your
brightest specimen OF genius-one VINO mas
the Promethean spark in his soul, who LOOKS
upon the landscape and loves it--who sees
virtue and tails PROSTATE at its shrine-ahu
vet ractices yce-Nice is relative term
the Hndoo priest. who urges the widow 70
mount the funeral pile of murder is less
guilty of crime on account of his ignorance,
than the Christian who breaks less morai
tie. Sogenius, (which knows the right and
yet the wrong pursucs" is vicious when COM
pared with folly.


! How few of the favored sons OF talent act
up to their high profession. In all arts III
all sciences, genius, like comet, Is ever &C.
centric, and its irregularty, comparatively
speaking, is a crime--can 1t be reduced TO
consistencyl can education and mind be LED
to adop, the plain morality of an honest yeo-
man!


Method is every thing-a virtuous sys-
TEN will prove an overmatch for evil habits;
and Saturday Evening should recall one
from the troubles and outward assaults OF
the world to an inward communication with
himself. his conduct, his location as to here
and hereafter. 1t should be like the cottage
of the lover and the iaborcr-he should sit
down beside the freside of his own heart,
call around him his children. which are his
thoughts and with them enter into judS-
ment as to the past, and from this calculate
upon better things to be performed In the
future. Men read history to be informed OF
the past--thcy gravely calculate from pre-,
diction what may ensue from the aspect ol
the present political world--and yet forgc'
to look at the past Of their own lives, and tc
draw a horoscope of their future existence
even upon earth. The world is selfish, 1t Is
sad--and yet how little of mans life IS de-
voted to himself True it is that ambition
claims part-the love of Distinction O
pleasure, of ease, are creditors which cair
more-but real selfshness, which is asld'
from these outward objects, and which re


ates to the settlement of our accounts Will
ourselves, takes no part in the drama OF eX


stence; and is untried before the forum o


conscience.


How seldom do we strive to be acquainted


with ourselves! with the springs OF actor


which govern us-the course OF life whlcl


we pursue-the very detail of criminal care


lessness which marks our conduct--all unno


tced as we sweep onward to death.


Is there no remedy?--let each Saturda.


night sit in Judgment upon the other SIX day


of the week, and let the Sabbath be devot


ed to virtuous resolutions, penitcnce all


prayer.

from personal attraction. Still we must
grant, that even in ancient times, those wo-
men who governed the heart and understand
ing of men with the most unbounded sway,
owed their power less to the witchery OF
beauty and the charms of youth, than to
their strength of mind and cultivation OF
talent. A woman of elegant personal exte-
rior, without the polish of accomplishment,
is like a flower without perfume. Aspasia
possessed neither youth nor beauty when
Socrates became her disciple, and imbibed
the principles of the philosophy OF love at
her feet; and her charms were faded when
Athens was governed by her DEGREES thro'
the medium of Pericles. Cornna, OF whose
talents we read so much, and of whose beau
ty we knew so little, presided over the stu
dies as well as the heart of Pindar 1he
splendid abilities of Catharine OF Russia
raised her from a cottage to throne. MAD
anne de Maintenon in the decline OF lite, by
the magnetism OF her conversation, and the
briliancy Of her ccomplishmentS, had more
power over the heart and councils OF tue
despotic Louis XIV, than the tascinatina
La Nallierc in all the winning attactons Of
youth, or Montespan in all the aliuvinN
( splendour Of beauty; if we are to credit tht
! assertions OF Dio, the only gailantry tht
voice OF scandal could lay to the charge o
I Cicero, was his devoted attachment and IT
erary correspondence with CGscllia, te


male wit and philosopher OF seventy.
has been acknowledged by the Empero


Napoleon that tho colloquial briliancy ant
gay vivacity OF Josephine could chase ava.
the gloomy spirit Of care itom his perturbat
ed mind sooner than the conjugal endeal


mcnts OF the lovely daughter OF the Caesars


A woman merely beautiful may attract;


woman polished, with mediocrlty OF edu


cation, may please, aud both united ma.
have a transient triumph over the heart 0


man; but il is sense and virtue, embellishc'


by the graccs Of accomplishments, that onl.


fasten on the mind and encian the affection


if to those precious qualities are added am


masion of temper, cheerful disposition, an'


softness of manners the power ot thelr pos


SCISSOR becomes altogether irresistible, 1t


fondy acknowledged by the heart-it Is rat


fled by tho understanding, and 1T cHalts eV


erv delight the senses can bestow.


'"I.a,ly Morgan isa fearless woman, and tn


most talented IN Europe

full articles.headline: ErrGCT OF SgGHT
full articles.article:
The following account of the behaviour OF
person born blind, upon receiving his
sight at twenty years OF age, by the opera
ton of an oculist. is from the American Sen
tncl.


The operator DIR. Grant, having ohscrv-
ed the eyes of his patient, and convincing
his relatives and friends. that it was highly
probable he could remove tho obstacle which
prevented his sight, all his ac1uaintances,
who had any curiosity to be present. when
one tull of age and understanding was to re-
receive new sense, assembled themselves
on this occasion, but were desired to pre-
serve profound silence in case sight was re.
stored in order to let the patient make his
own observations without the advantage ot
discovering his friends BY their voices A.
mong many others, the mother, brethcrn,
sister, and a young lady for whom lie had
formed particular attachment were pres
ent The operation was pert'rmcd with
great skill, SO that sight was instantly pro-
duccd


When the patient first received the dawn
! Of light, there appeared such an ecstacy in
! his action, that he seemed ready to swoon
away in the surprise OF joy and wonder-
4 The surgeon stood before him with his in
strum ept in his hands.--The patient obscrv-
ed him from head to foot, and then obselV-
ed himself as carefully, and comparing the
doctor to himself, he observed both hands
we're exactly alike, except the Instruments


which he took for part OF the doctors hands.


When he had continued in this amazement
for several minutes his mother could no
longer hear the agitation of so many passions


as thronced upon her, but tell upon his neck,
CRYING out "my son, my son. ihe young


gentleman knew her voice, and could say


no more than 40 me, are you my QeGr mo-
tber," and fanted.-On his recovery, he


heard the voice Of his female friend, which
had surprising effect upon him. Having


called her to him, he appeared to view her


with admiration and delight, and asked her


uhat had been done to him Whittier, said


he am carried Is all this about me the


thing which have heard SO often OF! rs
this seeing? Were you always thus happy


when YOU were so glad to see each othert--


Where is Tom who used to lead me: but


methinks could go now any where without


him.


He attempted to walk alone, but seemed


terrified When they saw this difficulty


they told him that till he became better ac-
E ouainted with his being, he must let the ser


Won't s,ill lead him. The boy being present
q
he took him to be before he had seen him'
He answered.. he believed he was not SC
, larpe as himself, but that he was the same
sort of a creature.
9 The rumor of this sudden change made al
tbe neighbours throng to see him. And as
he he saw the crowd gathering, he asked Tho
{ Doctor how many in all were to be SEEM


HE nhvsician replied, that il would be yer,
y -. 'for him TO return to his late condition
pnJp., pnd suffer his eyes to be covered for few
: davs. until they should receive strength, o
= : ,hsv would lose the power of aHordng hin
. that wonderful transport he was in. Witt
= much reluctance he was prevailed upon t
$ 5 have his eyes covered, in which eonditio
o thew kept him in a dark room, till it wa
. nropsr @ to let the organ receive its object
y without any further precaution. After Sc
v yeral days il was thought proper to unhn

full articles.headline: A MOTHERS PRAYER.
full articles.article:
Father of all! whose love has given
The boon that lifts my thoughts to heaven!
Teach me to guard with watclful care
The treasure thou hast sent me here
AND while my purest feelings flow,
With warm affections fullest glowi
oh let thy strength pcrvade my heart,
Aud teach me all a mothers part
ms CHERISHED babe which fills my arms,
And cheers me with its opening charms,
As thine in life, is thine in death;-
us earliest and its latest breath
Zane, and must go at thy decree
us life is only lent to me!


Then teach me with thy heavenly skill
io wait obedicntly thy viii!


and while train its thoughts to rise
from earth towards its native skies,
may my trembling heart prepare
nnoyleld it to thy heavenly care,
W Mhen thy sad messenger shall come
bear ito its safest home.


~. nut II thy mercy spares it now,


e's go schldhood's bloom, to manhood's S glow.
s.in s.,i let thy precepts be its guide,
n'lli let thy law of love abide,


rof none but those who OWN thy SWAY
Sah safely tread the narrow way

full articles.headline:
From The Museum.
STANZAS FOR MUSIC.
full articles.article:
III THE REV. T. DALE.
go, breathe no more that simple air,
Though soft and sweet thy wild notes swell
To me the only tale they tell


Is cold despair
heard it on from lips as fair.
heard it in as sweet q tone
Now am left on earth alone


And She is-where'
How have those well-known sounds renewed
The dreams Of earlier, happier hours,
When ltc--a desert now-was strewea


With fairy fiowers!--
Then all was bright, and fond, and tmr'-
Now flowers are faded, joys are He'd
And heart and hope are with the dead


For she ls-where'
Can then love the air she loved
Can then hear the melting strain
Which brings her to my soul again


Calm and unmov'd'-
And thou to blame my tears forbear;
For while list, sweet mad! to thee,
Remembrance whispers, such was she,'-


And she is where"

!, nav, perhaps, be unnecessary Tor ,iie ll',o,
-.l.;a,, or some of those who mry read the ioi-
having exquisite lines, TO state, that 'ro'' .,ie
nopny is distilled that drug OF power 20 soo'ne
rrr slay-to madden or to mitigate, OPIUM. hefe
!" hcauty. nathos and delicacy in this ode that
"ill reach every hcart--N T. inner


ODE TO THE POPPY.


BIZ Ms. ONsnL
NJ, f,r the nro,nisc of the labor'd field,
Not for the GOOD the yellow harvests YIELD
lbend at Ceres shrine;
For duh to humid eyes appear
The goldeu gorics of the year,


Alas! a melancholy worship mhe.
| hail the goddess tor her scarlet ho"et'


Thou brilliant weed,


That dost So far exceed


Tho richest gifts gay Flora can bestowi
Needless / pns,'d thee in fes morning hour,
Thou comforter Of woe,
Till sorrow taught inc to confess thy power
In earliest days, when fancy chea'7,
A various wreath woye,
ofhughing Springs lnxuriant sweets,
10 deck ungratcful love-
The rose or thorns my numbers cro"hd,
As Venus smiled or Venus trown'di


But love and Joy and all their tram are fown
E'en languid hope no more rs minc,


And will sing Of thee alone;


Unlcss pcrchance the attributes OF Gret


The cypress bud and willow Leaf,
Their pale funercal foliage blend with thine
Hail lovely bosom thou canst ease
The wretched victim of disease,


Canst close those weary eyes III sleep
Which never open but to wcep


For oh! thy potent charm,


Can agonizing pain dlsarlfi.
Expel imperous memory from her seat,
And bid the throbbing heart forget to beat.
Soul soothing plant that can such blessing give,
By thee the mourner loves to live,


BY thee the hopeless die,


Oh! ever friendly to despair,


Might sorrows pallid votary dare,
without a crime that remedy timplore
which bids the spirit from its bondage ny
ia court thy pallating aid no more,


Nomore I'd sue that thou shoudst spFeat
Thy spell around my aching head,


But would coniure thee to impart,


Thy balsam fora broken heart,


And by thy soft I.ethean power,


Inestmable flower.
Hurst these terrestrial bands and other region


try.

full articles.headline: GENERAL WASHINGTON,
full articles.article:
'''NH''SS'TN'~S'


fCoScLUDEn.l


When Col Washington first resided AZ
Mount Vernon, both the mansion house and
estate were inconsiterabe. All the em5el-
lishments of the house and grounds are ow-
iEr to his creative hand. Prior TO the war
of independence, he was much attached 10
the pleasures of the chase, and Is described
AS a bold and fearless rider. He Kept
hounds for short time after the Revolution,
but declined hunting altogether about 1857
or '88.


He was never disposed to conviviallty, but
liked the cheerful converse OF the social
board; indulging in no games OF chance' eH-
cept in the oldcn times, when required 10
make up party at whist, in playing tor
trlfle, although for many years, play OF al
kinds was unknown in his household. At
ter his retirement from public lie, all the
time he could spare from his library, was
devoted to the improvement OF his estates,
and the elegant and tasteful arrangement OF
his house and grounds He was his own
surveyor; and the disposition and appear
ance Of his farms, gave evident proofs that
the genius of useful improvement had d.
rected it's energies with beneficial as well as
ornamental effects.


Asa master Of slaves, General Washing
ton was consistent, as in every other rela-
ton of his meritorious life. They were
comfortably lodged, Ted, and clothed; re-
Qnired to do full and tair share OF duty
we'll cared for in sickness and old age, ana
kept in strict and proper discipline These,
we humbly conceive, comprise all the char-
tiles Of slavery To his old servants, whose
long and faithful services rendered them
worthy Of attachment and esteem. he vas
most kind. Ills huI tsman and Revolutions
~ attendant, WIN Lee, commonly called
Billy, was specially provided tor, and sur
yivcd his master a good many years. WIN
had been stout, active man, and famous
horseman, but, from accident, was Cripple
MANY years before his death, which occur
J red at a very advanced age. This ancient
( follower, both in the chase and war, formed
most Interesting relic of the Chief, and
received considerable largcssc from the vis'
tiers to Mount Vernon. The slaves were
\ left. TO be emancipated at the death OF Mrs
WA ohingten; but it was found necessary
! (fOr Hrudenta.k rcasons) to give them then
/ freedom in one year after the Generals de-
cease. Although many of them, with
view to their liberation, had been instructed
in mechanic trades, yet they succeeded very
badly as freemen: so true is the MAXIM
"that the hour which makes man slave
takes half his worth away"


Bishop, an English soldier, formed an IN
tercsting reminisccnce oi the war OF 90
He belonged to BraddocA's own regiment
and, OH account of possessing superior intel
ligence, was detained as a body servant, tf
accompany that i'll fated commander on the
expedition to Fort du Quesnc. Bishop firmly
believed in the Providence Which shielded
the Provincial Major, i'll the memorable bat
tic of Monongahcla. and observed, he wa
the only mounted officer left The enem,
knew him well, from their having felt hin
severely, the year before, at the affair OF th


Meadows and the provincial militia bcln'
far more obnoxious to the French and IN
dians that the European troops, from tn
craftsmanship of the rangers, and their III
innate knowledge of the modes OF tores
warfare, the fire of the enemy became sin
gulary directed against the devoted yonn


warrior, whom they afterwards termed "th


spirit protected man." destined to "bccom


the Chief of Nations and "vho coul


not die in battle" The hat worn on tina


cventful day, and which was pierced by tw


balls, was at Mount Vernon, and both see
and handled by several persons, long with


our remembrance; yet strange to sa! It wa
no WneTe 10 Ut tOuHu O!I tHe GShiioS Va -.
Chief Another and invaluable relic was al
, so missing; we mean the sword OF service
which was worn in action, in the war of IN
, dependence. 1t was described to us, by OH
+ who oft had buckled it to the here's SIDE, a
being kind of hanger; and we have an IL
, disticnt recollection of having been told
> the family, that it was given to Greene
, the close OF the war. If 50, it surely coul
not have been more worthiy bestowed. VI
5 on mentioning these circumstances to Get
: eral Andrew Jackson, he was pleased to sa
4 tha. he would make inquiry among the d

HIS LIFE, HABITS, AND MANNERS.


From the "Ci4stjs Recyllcct;ons."

full articles.headline: SONG.
full articles.article:
SONG.
In early youth, when hope was high,
Gaily / sang oflovc and truths
But those S Seet hours are all gone by,
Gone the dear dreams of early youth
O that such dazzling dreams should fade!
How happy would life's journey prove,
Where friendships bosom ne'er betray'd,
Nor wounded oer the heart Of love!

The proud to gain it, tolls on tolls endure
The modest shun il, but TO make it shurei
1t aids the dancers heel, the writer's head,
And heaps the plains, with mountains OF the


dead;


Nor ends with death, but mods in sable plunes,
l,cdecks the heavens, and hatters on our tombs.

SCendantS OF Greene, VINO, IL tncy pcSsesss
will, no doubt, most dearly prize, so vaua-
ble a gift as the Sgvord Of the Revolution.


At the commencement OF the hostilitles,
in l775, Bishop being too old for active SER
vice, was left at home in charge of the man.
ufacturing establishments of the household.
where the veteran would flourish his cane,
exactng as perfect obedience as though he
had been ON parade. A comfortable house
had been built for him; he had married; and
looking no more toward his native land, he
was contented to pass the remainder OF his
DAYS on the domain of his patron, where he
rested from labor, in the enjoyment of eve
ry possible ease and indulgence-the re-


ward of his long and faithful services. In
his comfortable homestead, and hoary with


age, he would delight the young with tales


of fearful interest of the Indian wars, while


his own wars ended, at peace with the world,


he feebly trimmed the lamp of life, which,
having burned for more than eighty years,


could but for little longer be kept from


sinking in its socket


otwithstanding his perfect reverence for


his patron, this old soldier weuld sometimes.


presuming on the privilege of age and long


services, chafe his protector on points of ex-
! pedency, though never on those of obedi-


cnce. The General would assume lofty


tone, saying it is very WE'LL sir; if you are at


length tired of my service, you are at per-


feet liberty to depart. The ancient follow


er of Braddock, however, knew his man,


and knew exactly what was best to do; he


wisely became silent; and the storm which


appeared to be brooding quickly passed e.


way, when a returning sunshine cheered
with the warmth of its kindness the veteran


of '56.


The Washington family were subjected


10 hereditary gout-the Chief never expert
enced pang. His temperance, and the en-
, ergetic employment of both his body and


mind, seemed to forbid the approach of a dis


ease. which severely afflicted several of his


kindred. His illnesses were of rare occur


renee, but were particularly severe; his a


version to the uses of medicine was extreme:


for, even when in great suffering, it was only


by the entreaties of his lady, and the respect


tul, yet beseeching look, of his oldest friend
and companion in arms, (Dr. James Craik, }


chat he could be prevailed upon to take the


slightest preparation of medicine. He cer-


tanly never had children. We recolect a


lady who called herself his daughter. She
was a fine looking woman, but without any


particular likeness to the Chief, nor can we
consider that as pardonabe vanity in


child, which duplicates the honor OF pa


rent.


The remarkable degree Of admiration and


awe that was felt by every one, upon the
, first approach to Washington, evidences the


imposing power and sublimity which belongs
to real greatness. Even the frequenters Of
the Courts OF Princes were sensible of this
, exalted feeling, when in the presence of the
hero, who, formed for the highest desti-
nics. bore an impress from nature, which
| declared him to be one among the noblest Of
her works.


Those who have only seen the Lead
, er of Armies and the Chief Magistrate of
the Republic can have but an imperfect idea
, of the same being, when merged in the re-
tired citizen, embosomed amid his family
/ and friends, cultivating the social and domes
: tic virtues, and difusing pleasure and hap
! piness to all around him.


$ Persons in general have been in error, in
e supposing that there belonged to this awful
: man nothing of the gentler sort-"no tear
I for pity" The Master Spirit in the dircc-
i tion os those vast events which gave a new
d empire to the world, the austerity of COM
+. mand conld never destroy those kindlicr
e feelings in which he delighted mself to in
!, dulrc, and to dispense them to Others
/, Stern he was to all whom he deemed waat-
T. ing in tAose high moral requisites, which dig
nify and adorn our natures--stern he was to
a the disturbers Of the repose OF Society. the
i vioaters of those institutes which promote
y peace and good will among men; but he was
!, forbearing to the imperfectons of humac
!, kind, where they arose from the passions


only, and not the dcpravities of the heart.
: He was reserved to the many, but there
= were chosen few, who, having passed thai
!; barrier, were wooed by his friendship t
+ push their fortunes, till they finally gainee
o footing in the citadel of his esteem.


e He had a tear-tor we have seen it shct
y with parental solicitude over the manifold
d errors and folles of our unworthy youth
t. lie shed a tear Of sorrow for his suffering
IS country in the dark hour of her destiny, anl
y a tear of joy and gratitude to Heaven for hel
n dcliverance--when,i in 1889. he crossed the
e Bridge Of Trenton; on which classic spo
g the hands of frcemen "reared tor him til
l. umphal bowers" while choir of innocents
e with seraph chant. welcomed the mighty
J. Chief once MORE" and 'virgins fair, ane
st matrons grave, strewed the hero's way witt
, flowers"
,g The Journey Of the first President to tn,
,e Seat of Government was one continued tri
,e umpb; but no where was it of so feeling
Id character as at the bridge of Trenton. Tha
At was indeed a classic ground 1t was there
70 on a frozen surface. that, in 1776, was u
m chicved the glorious event which restored

full articles.headline: PRAISE.
full articles.article:
p.;sve rove OF praise, howe'er concealed by art,
iiiSRS more Or less, and glows in every heart
